data.title: Notify if build tools and SDK API is not up to date
data.body:
- Moves build tools version and api level to DependencyBank.
- Updates bundled gitignore

data.title: Fix please deadlock race condition with quick resume/pause in com.badlogic.gdx.backends.android.AndroidGraphics
1.0 version hello world crash using freetype on iphone 5
QueryAABB is not working
data.body: Nevermind got it working and don't see how to delete. Sorry.

data.title: 1.2 Box2dLights release
Patch for the Setup. Remove android dependency. Add version Options.
data.body:
This adds a few tweaks to the setup:
- Adds the ability to select version of libgdx 1.0.0+, as well as choose to be put onto the nightlies.
- Removes dependency on Android when you dont have the project selected, no local.properties file is generated, nor will the project check if the sdk location is valid, in fact it disables the field to provide some better feedback.
- Puts box2dlights onto the 2-SNAPSHOT until its released.
- Remove duplicate dependency of x86 natives in the android backend.
- Some visual tweaks like cursors in the text fields

data.title: Wrong version of box2dlights when using gdx-setup
data.body:
When adding box2dlights extension in gdx-setup it sets the version to `1.2` but it won't work because it doesn't exist in [sonatype](https://oss.sonatype.org/content/repositories/snapshots/com/badlogicgames/box2dlights/box2dlights/), the correct is `1.2-SNAPSHOT`

```
dependencies {
    compile "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx:$gdxVersion"
    compile "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-box2d:$gdxVersion"
    compile "com.badlogicgames.box2dlights:box2dlights:1.2" // should be 1.2-SNAPSHOT
}
```

data.title: Added Vector#interpolate(...) method to integrate different Interpolation methods for vectors.
data.body:
I've added a little utility function making it easier to use different Interpolation methods on the math vectors.
This is an adition to the lerp(...) method which only supports linear interpolation. I used the new method name for clarity and to avoid breaking the API.

I've also adapted the Vector2dTest a bit to show it works in there as well.

data.title: Fixes #1726 (precision problems in intersectSegmentPolygon and intersectLinePolygon).
data.body:
Replaces intersectSegmentPolygon and intersectLinePolygon "optimized"
implementations with the more robust implementations used for intersectLine and
intersectSegments

data.title: Double line in generated project
data.body:
I jut run latest gdx gradle project generator and in text see this:

project(":android") {
    apply plugin: "android"

```
configurations { natives }

dependencies {
    compile project(":core")
    compile "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-backend-android:$gdxVersion"
    natives "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-platform:$gdxVersion:natives-x86"
    natives "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-platform:$gdxVersion:natives-armeabi"
    natives "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-platform:$gdxVersion:natives-armeabi-v7a"
    natives "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-platform:$gdxVersion:natives-x86"
    compile "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-box2d:$gdxVersion"
    natives "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-box2d-platform:$gdxVersion:natives-armeabi"
    natives "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-box2d-platform:$gdxVersion:natives-armeabi-v7a"
    natives "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-box2d-platform:$gdxVersion:natives-x86"
}
```

}

Double line - natives "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-platform:$gdxVersion:natives-x86"

data.title: .gitignore in gdx-setup is not working like intended
data.body:
The default .gitignore file that the gdx-setup creates, does not work how it was inteded for the latest versions of git.

The .gitignore file contains the following lines (amongst other similar ones):
- libs/armeabi/
- libs/armeabi-v7a/
- libs/x86/

Older versions of git seem to have recursively applied that pattern to all subdirectories (like android/libs/armeabi/), but the latest version doesn't seem to do this anymore when the pattern includes more than just 1 folder.

For me, the native libs *.so in those folders are not ignored. To include recursive matches, it seems like the patterns have to look like this now:
- **/libs/armeabi/
- **/libs/armeabi-v7a/
- **/libs/x86/

Just the deepest folders also work, but they might hit incorrect folders (in case those folders exist anywhere else and should not be excluded):
- armeabi/
- armeabi-v7a/
- x86/

The same problem should exist for the following patterns:
- nbproject/private/
- war/gwt_bree/
- war/WEB-INF/deploy/
- war/WEB-INF/classes/

data.title: Nightlies should be 1.1.0-SNAPSHOT
data.body: Since you are following http://semver.org/ I would think the nightly would point to the next minor version update and then you cut official patch releases as you progress on that nightly version. Just a thought.

data.title: Stop IDE's thinking android is required when it isn't. Resolves #1739
data.body: local.properties file is only included if the android sub module is selected.

data.title: Cross-platform I18N support
data.body:
Internationalization / localization is a very important aspect of many apps, not least games.
I'm working on a cross-platform I18N package for my libgdx apps.
My work is heavily inspired to ResourceBundle + Control class from java.util which is something all Java developers are used to.
Unlike java.util.ResourceBundle, it works for Android 2.2 too (Control class has been introduced in API level 9).
It provides all the main features of java.util.ResourceBundle but I've removed some less common stuff:
- ListResourceBundle aren't supported anymore. But who cares. Be honest, have you ever used it? :) 
- you can't specify the ClassLoader anymore, which is something needed only by servlet containers and stuff like that, I guess. This should help to make it gwt compatible, but I'm a noob with gwt so it's just speculation.

Then I've implemented a FileControl class that can work with any gdx FileType and any encoding. If you don't specify any control when creating a bundle a default control is used, i.e. a FileControl with FileType.Internal and ISO-8859-1 encoding.
Users can also implement their own control class to support other sources (e.g. http instead of file system) and formats (e.g. xml instead of properties).

When it's finished - it works already for desktop and adroid platforms but some code cleanup is needed - I'll do a pull request if you're interested in.
In this case I'll need your help to support the gwt backend too.
What do you think? Suggestions, ideas?

     Required by:
         test:android:1.0
```

data.title: Missing btCollisionDispatcher callbacks
data.body:
Currently the only way to filter collisions in bullet is via a mask-based selection system, or via the AABBs of the CollisionObjects (basically all information that are accessible in the broadphase callbacks).

In some situations this mechanism isn't enough and one needs full control over the collision filtering by accessing the collision object's `userData`. This could be done via the `btCollisionDispatcher.needsCollision(btCollisionObject, btCollisionObject)` and `btCollisionDispatcher.needsResponse(btCollisionObject, btCollisionObject)`. They are basically equivalent to the Box2D `ContactFilter.shouldCollide(Fixture, Fixture)`, where one can also access the userData via `fixture.getUserData()`.

Currently a `CustomCollisionDispatcher extends btCollisionDispatcher` is not recognized by the native code and no callbacks to the custom dispatcher takes place. For very complex games with many different entities which can collide with each other, or can't, or sometimes can, or collide after a delay etc., the usual broadphase filtering isn't powerful enough anymore and finding a valid filtermask based solution would become extremely hard to maintain.

Thus it would be great if the libgdx <-> bullet bridge could handle custom collision dispatchers.

data.title: Move DebugDrawer
Update fetch.xml
data.body: Add missing directories for the Box2D extension

data.title: Make tools only compatible with the desktop subproject, resolves #1727
VoxelTest - Textures
data.body:
While trying to getting used to the framework and learning things I stumbled across the VoxelTest. Since I want to redo my voxel-based game with libgdx I thoroughly studied the code.
Well now, my problem is that despite you setting everything up for textured blocks by passing a TextureRegion[][] over to the world, you never use or bind any (sub-)textures and thus the chunks are only varying in color and have no textures at all.
Can somebody please tell me how to implement textures to a voxel world?
Or even better, write it in the VoxelTest itself?

Greetings,
   Dakror

data.title: UnsatisfiedLinkError when using Box2D extension
data.body:
After generating new build.gradle files, I was able to get my project almost back up and running with Box2D. My projects build fine with the new gradle files.

These lines are present in the root build.gradle:

```
project(":desktop") {
    apply plugin: "java"
        dependencies {
            compile project(":core")
            compile "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-backend-lwjgl:$gdxVersion"
            compile "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-platform:$gdxVersion:natives-desktop"
            compile "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-box2d-platform:$gdxVersion:natives-desktop"
            compile "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-freetype-platform:$gdxVersion:natives-desktop"
            compile "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-controllers-desktop:$gdxVersion"
            compile "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-controllers-platform:$gdxVersion:natives-desktop"
        }
}
```

However, whenever I try to run the desktop version, I get this UnsatisfiedLinkError:

```
Exception in thread "LWJGL Application" com.badlogic.gdx.utils.GdxRuntimeException: java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: com.badlogic.gdx.physics.box2d.PolygonShape.newPolygonShape()J
```

I haven't tried running the other versions, but I suspect the same error will crop up. I noticed someone else also [reported getting this error](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/23162845/polygonshape-native-method-not-found-using-new-libgdx-gradle-project).

Everything looks like it's set up just fine, so I'm not sure what the problem could be

data.title: Box2d physics stopped working on gradle project
data.body:
I was trying to use the box2d library under "com.badlogic.gdx.physics" together with the 1.0-SNAPSHOT version of libgdx. Suddenly after a gradle sync, everything under "com.badlogic.gdx.physics" suddenly disappeared.

I've tried to generate a new project from libgdx-setup.jar and that project couldn't find the "com.badlogic.gdx.physics" package just like my own project.

data.title: Allow exclusions of transitive dependencies
build.gradle should include gdx-tools extension for desktop project only
data.body:
When creating a test project using the new setup (plus extensions including gdx-tools) the error below occurs when building the Android project.

I solved the error by removing the line `compile "com.badlogicgames.gdx:gdx-tools:$gdxVersion"` from `project(":core")`.

Perhaps by default, gdx-tools should be included only in gradle's desktop project rather than in the core? If I understand correctly, then https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/wiki/Dependency-management-with-Gradle#tools-gradle should also be updated to reflect this.

    (net.java.games.input.WinTabEnvironmentPlugin$4) that doesn't come with an
    associated EnclosingMethod attribute. This class was probably produced by a
    compiler that did not target the modern .class file format. The recommended
    solution is to recompile the class from source, using an up-to-date compiler
    and without specifying any "-target" type options. The consequence of ignoring
    this warning is that reflective operations on this class will incorrectly
    indicate that it is *not* an inner class.
    trouble processing "javax/xml/namespace/QName.class":
    Ill-advised or mistaken usage of a core class (java.* or javax.*)
    when not building a core library.
    This is often due to inadvertently including a core library file
    in your application's project, when using an IDE (such as
    Eclipse). If you are sure you're not intentionally defining a
    core class, then this is the most likely explanation of what's
    going on.
    However, you might actually be trying to define a class in a core
    namespace, the source of which you may have taken, for example,
    from a non-Android virtual machine project. This will most
    assuredly not work. At a minimum, it jeopardizes the
    compatibility of your app with future versions of the platform.
    It is also often of questionable legality.
    If you really intend to build a core library -- which is only
    appropriate as part of creating a full virtual machine
    distribution, as opposed to compiling an application -- then use
    the "--core-library" option to suppress this error message.
    If you go ahead and use "--core-library" but are in fact
    building an application, then be forewarned that your application
    will still fail to build or run, at some point. Please be
    prepared for angry customers who find, for example, that your
    application ceases to function once they upgrade their operating
    system. You will be to blame for this problem.
    If you are legitimately using some code that happens to be in a
    core package, then the easiest safe alternative you have is to
    repackage that code. That is, move the classes in question into
    your own package namespace. This means that they will never be in
    conflict with core system classes. JarJar is a tool that may help
    you in this endeavor. If you find that you cannot do this, then
    that is an indication that the path you are on will ultimately
    lead to pain, suffering, grief, and lamentation.
    1 error; aborting
```

data.title: Precision problems with Intersector.intersectSegmentPolygon
